comments.text:
Basically, a part of your body gets really hot. If it gets hot enough, the 
proteins and other compounds that make up your cells start breaking down, 
and undergoing chemical changes (denaturing) because of the heat. Once this 
happens, that tissue is basically dead. Beyond that tissues dehydrate, die, 
and sustain damage.

Your body responds by rushing blood to the area to cool the burn down and 
begin repairs. It also begins releasing chemicals that cause swelling in 
the area. This is why burns are red. If the burn is worse, blisters are 
formed. Blisters are sacks of fluid your body produces in order to protect 
the healing damaged tissue. Blisters should contain clear fluid. They can 
also contain blood, which is usually caused by a forceful injury, or pus if 
the blister got infected. If the burn is worse still, it can burn holes 
through the skin, or even through all the way through to the bone.

Depending on the severity of the burn you can lose sensation in the part 
due to damaged nerves. burns can also result in skin that lacks pores, 
meaning the skin can no longer sweat, or, I think, produce the natural 
protective oils that keep your skin hydrated.

On the blue LEDs. How do you calculate that it's actually "white"? In 
computer science, white can be defined as either the hexcode "#FFFFFF", or 
the RGB "255,255,255", but measuring color outside of the computer is done 
via measuring the wavelength in nanometers, but since white is the 
combination of all colors, you can't just add up all the frequencies or 
else you will get something infra-red (or longer), and I don't think you 
can take the average, or else you'll get the color in the middle of the 
light spectrum (I think it's green), so how would you go about measuring 
the frequency of a white light, or to put it another way, what is the 
frequency of white light?﻿

comments.text:
White LEDs are actually blue LEDs in disguise.  Based on how thick each 
layer of GaN is deposited, the emission wavelength of the device changes.  
Since an LED can only emit one wavelength, there are several layers of GaN 
in the device that emit blue, green, and red wavelengths giving a pseudo 
white emission spectrum.  If you look at a spectral output of a white LED 
you will see sharp peaks in Red, Green and Blue wavelengths.  For more 
information read about LED microfabrication and GaN fabrication.
comments.author: Crobisaur

comments.text:
White light doesn't have a wavelength because it isn't a single color. The 
'White light' coming from a computer screen for example isn't true white 
light, because you will only find red, green, and blue. In fact, why it 
looks white is actually a trick. Red and Green (at the same time) will 
stimulate your red and green receptors the same way yellow light does, but 
it won't fool an actual yellow light sensor. Absolutely white light has 
level emission across the spectrum.

comments.text:
+Darth Obscurity "Any chance you could give us an example when the market 
chose helping people over making money? "

The market doesn't make money. Businesses, run by humans, individuals, 
capitalize of the market to gain wealth.

I return back to my story about Rockefeller see my Nov 19th comment)...

"Rockefeller saw plumes of smoke and slag oil being tossed into the trash 
and he chose on his own to refine oil better, create less pollution and get 
better fuels.

Some other people saw that the left over oil that was tossed out could 
become clothing, cleaners, plastics and so on."

If you want to see examples of making products better (nearly impossible to 
see without government interference, but...) we can look to many products 
and businesses.

During the 2008 "great recession" many companies' heads took little to no 
salary in order to not reduce workforce. Many companies have offered health 
insurance and retirement without the force of law.

You can certainly say that before the Enlightenment and the Great 
Awakening, more focus was on the wealth of the person in charge, but it was 
always the government (church was a defacto government) who run the 
production and if there were any businesses and business men who could 
capitalize, it was a family run business or kept very small.

When the industrial age came about, you had a transition from old 
mentalities (as humans may evolve, but they are not always as fast to 
rethink thins, as you can see we still tend to the government is needed to 
run our live model even today). But as getting government to let the market 
run on its own is a new idea (historically speaking). and few countries 
today even come close, you only see the system working in these few 
companies here and there.

"If there is a big machine with exposed moving parts that can grab and kill 
you if you get to close but the company won't put a guard rail up because 
it costs money, would they ever without an external force coming in and 
telling them to? "

Hard to say, as a company that has large machines like that are often 
propped up by the government rather than allowed market forces. The closest 
you could find is the farming industry and you do find that the farmer will 
but new machines that aren't as dangerous when they buy new machinery. But 
many will continue to use a knife or a simple cutting instrument. In that, 
it is their choice, but those often have few employees and make no money 
... until the government tries to save the family farms.

The external force is what makes changes. It is usually the invisible hand 
or it is a ruler. Bottom up or top down.

In your example of a guard rail, there have been companies who put one up 
because they can't maintain a workforce without that simple change. There 
are other companies that don't and the employees do the democratic thing 
and collectively fight it. Unions aren't bad until they become the ruling 
class and a defacto government, not allowing competition.

But when you look at the various things that stayed static under the 
government while technology soared without the burden, or even the things 
that had a time under one, then a time under the other, you see that 
letting the free market take the lead is often better than the government.

Look at the Internet. You have people complaining about the businesses 
running and choking bandwith. Really? When the military was running the 
arpnet development (1960-1980), it was just them and research scientists. 
They called in private researchers to help develop the system, but it 
wasn't until the late 1980s to 1990s that it sped up for public use. And 
once it was handed to the public without the regulations, it went from 300 
baud dial-up that cost $1 per minute and took hours to download a small, 
fuzzy GIF to DSL to Cable and fiber optics that run fast enough to download 
a high def 3 hour movie in under a minute... while you watch it and talk on 
the Internet phone and email your friends and chat on Facebook.

And now the government says this is bad and they need to make it a utility?

"When it’s not feasible to have competition, i.e. internet, water,

Internet has wide competition. Water has major competition. I can chose my

Well, until government gets involved and tries to gain control rather than

comments.author: Benjamin Abruzzo

comments.text:
+Benjamin Abruzzo Arguing its negligible is not a valid argument your vote 
is negligible, it does not mean you should not vote. Like prominent law 
cases it also bring to the foreground the discussion about emission 
reduction and promotes a shift in that direction. 

The US government has shrunk relative to America’s growth over the past 100 
years. So yes the government is shrinking and all its programs along with 
it.

I should clarify when I use the term short term, long term I am and have 
specifically referred to the economic long run and short run. By definition 
every private company in a free market will short term profit maximise. The 
short term is relative to goods they are dealing with, and refers to the 
time period a company has to operate in without changing its capital, among 
other things. 

This is the main point I have been trying to make this whole time:

When a private company goes into business its goal will first and foremost 
be short term profit maximisation. If the market is saturated to the point 
where that includes being nice to customers so as to not lose their 
business, great, the wheels of the world are turning and well-oiled don’t 
fuck with it.
However when there is no competition and their goods are inelastic (can’t 
do without). These companies whose first goal is profit maximise will do 
just that at the expense of the consumer/employee and that’s us!

When does this happen? When it’s not feasible to have competition, i.e. 
internet, water, electricity etc. and of course employment opportunities.

comments.text:
+Netsuko Yoshikawa Yes.  That's because I was making a joke.
+Malidictus I'm fairly sure neither type of bulb produces "pure white 
light", partly because that's a contradiction in terms.  "Pure" light is 
monochromatic, whereas to be perceived as white a light source must have 
roughly equal spectral power against each of the three cone cell response 
curves - many spectra can achieve this, from the 'three narrow spikes' of 
the RGB LED to the black-body spectrum of a hot object.  Daylight and 
incandescent bulbs both have (approximately) black-body spectra.
While these spectra cannot be distinguished from direct transmission, they 
do produce different results after reflection from a surface - the 
trichromatic LED effectively samples the albedo at just three frequencies 
whereas the black-body effectively integrates the albedo spectrum against 
the cone cell response curve.  In theory it would be possible to make an 
object which appears white by broad-spectrum light but black by LED light.  
The reverse however would not be possible; an object that is white by LED 
light could be dark grey by broad-spectrum light, but not completely 
black.  Isn't that fascinating?  Mmm, science.
+Natasha Taylor Curiously, the "crisp white" light is technically 'warmer' 
than the "yellow glow"; look up 'colour temperature' and 'black-body 
radiation'.  Cool colours are emitted by hot objects, and vice-versa!

turned on and off. This will usually result in a shortened life. They also

comments.text:
+Cythil "I think the 8-track is a false analogy."

I think it works. The old vinyl albums were old and didn't fit the new wave 
of technology of hi-fi and cars and transistor radios. There was 
reel-to-reel magnetic tape and then hi-fi 8-tracks as the new groovy tech 
that you could take in cars and play in portable players.

But as fast as technology was back then, 8-tracks had only from 1965 till 
1982, 17 years. Meanwhile the cassette tape took the older ree;-to-reel 
idea and in 1950s it began rolling out the technology, not really ready, 
but growing. By 1971, the cassette tape took off and caused the downfall of 
the 8-track.

But CDs were on the beginning of their treck in 1980. By 1993 CDs took over 
for all magnetic tape, especially as computers were beginning to use CDs as 
well.

The album was an Edison invention, like the light bulb and both will be a 
novelty and be around for a long time, but for popular use, the new 
technology of magnetic tape was the future.

Reel-to-reel is the same as the old mercury tube lights. The cassette tapes 
are CFL, but the 8-track was a traditional medium in magnetic hi-fi.

CDs and DVDs are the LED technology and MP3s are all digital. I can't 
imagine an all digital light source, but it's out there.

This change was market driven, just as the switch over to CFLs and LED 
could easily have been.

I can't imagine what would have happened in the turbulent times of the 
1960s and 1970s if the "man" tried to ban magnetic tape and push CD tech 
before it was ready.

pollution changes based on another variable outside that bulb, then the 
bulb is not the issue, it is that outside variable.

they don't mention two things 1) that LEDs have been used in battery 
powered lamps and in flashlights and decorations for a long time, 
accounting for their penetration (Christmas lights alone are a major LED 
market) and 2) what happened before 2007 and the law banning IC bulbs.

As you can see in both charts, from 2008 to 2011 IC bulbs gained 
penetration. But the first link shows the hidden story. From 2003 to 2007 
CFLs were climbing by market forces alone to replace IC bulbs by 2009 or 
2010. But then in 2007 (the year the ban passed in the USA), CFL

captions.text: [Intro]

How do we see what's inside us? How do you
see me? How do I know where I'm going? These

are some of the questions answered by the
brightest minds in the word, 2014's Nobel
Prize winners in physics, medicine, and chemistry.

First, the Nobel Prize for physics, it went
to Isamu Akasaki, Hiroshi Amano, and Shuji

Nakamura for developing the blue light emitting
diode, or LED. This ridiculously useful invention

is the key to making possible the white LED
bulb. Which is replacing Thomas Edison's incandescent

bulb as the the light source of the 21st century.
LEDs are also in smartphones, and television

screens, and laptop screens, and desktop screens.
Probably if the LEDs in your computer turned

off right now, I would disappear. And I wouldn't
have a job!

An LED is a type of diode or semiconductor
device that emits light when electrons flow

through layers of crystalline inorganic material.
These diodes have been around since the 1950s,

but at first we were only able to make ones
that emitted either red or green light. And

those were still super useful; you've no doubt
seen them in watches, and calculators, and

all those little red lights on answering machines
- if you remember what answering machines

are. But the challenge was always to build
a diode that emitted white light. And that

required creating a combination of diodes
that together glowed in red, green, and blue.

The problem was blue light has a much shorter
wavelength than red and green light. And scientists

struggled for decades to find a material that
emitted light in that wavelength when electrons

based through it. It was until the 1980s that
these three laureates developed a high quality

layer of crystalline gallium nitrate that
did the trick.

Today, white LED bulbs are everywhere and
for good reason. They're a lot more energy

efficient than incandescent bulbs which lose
a lot of their energy through heat. LEDs convert

electricity directly into light, which means
they need less power. And considering that

a fourth of the world's total energy output
is spent on generating light, these scientists

deserve the prize as clearly as you're seeing
me right now.

For the winners of this year's chemistry prize,
light posed a different kind of challenge.

For centuries, scientists have been limited
by the fact that optical microscopes couldn't

achieve a resolution smaller than 0.2 micrometers,
or half the wavelength of visible light. This

has to do with how light diffuses through
a microscope's glass lens and was known as

Abbe's Diffraction Limit. This limit meant
that we could clearly see living cells, but

we couldn't see individual molecules or proteins
inside them. So in the 1980s and 90s, scientists

began experimenting with fluorescent microscopy.
Using gene-splicing technology to introduce

fluorescent, or glowing, molecules into a
cell. These molecules could then couple with

DNA and proteins to act as a kind of tracer.
And that was extremely helpful, but it didn't

solve the problem of seeing things that were
smaller than 0.2 micrometers. But this year's

chemistry winners came up with ways to break
Abbe's limit by inventing ways to turn fluorescence

of those molecules on or off, like a switch.
Making them clearly visible.

German chemist Stefan Hell did this by using
lasers. Essentially to turn on all of the

glowing molecules within a single nanometer;
that's a billionth of a meter. By slowly passing

the lasers over a cell, nanometer by nanometer,
he was able to create a detailed image of

a cell by highlighting groups of glowing molecules.
At the same time, two US scientists, Eric

Betzig and William Moerner, developed a similar
technique that uses pulses of light to turn

individual molecules on and off. Allowing
them to clearly stand out in the specimen.

Like with Hell's technique, they could repeat
this process lighting up different molecules

until they eventually created a super high
resolution image of structures as thin as

a cell membrane. Together these techniques
gave the world what's now known as super-resolved

fluorescence microscopy, allowing us to see
what goes on inside a living cell with visible
light.

Finally, we have the winners of this year's
prize in medicine. John O'Keefe, May-Britt

Moser, and Edvard Moser who discovered that
brains have an inner GPS that tells animals,

including us, where they are. O'Keefe discovered
the first clues to this system in 1971 while

studying rats. He noted that certain neurons
in the upper hippocampus, the region of the

brain responsible for memory and organization,
were always activated when a rat was in a

particular place in a room. O'Keefe named
these neurons "place cells". As the rat moved

around the room, different "place cells" would
fire. Through further research, O'Keefe concluded

that these cells were responsible for building
and storing mental maps. Then in 2005, May-Britt

and Edvard Moser conducted their own rat experiments
and discovered another set of neurons called

"grid cells". They're located in a part of
the brain called the entorhinal cortex, right

next to the hippocampus, and they're what
your brain uses to create a map-like grid

of any environment. The Mosers discovered
that these cells would not only fire whenever

a rat passed a particular location, but they
would go off again when it pointed its head
in the direction of that spot.

Together, these newly discovered sets of cells
basically make up the iPhone map in your brain

that you use to get around. O'Keefe's "place
cells" form the coordinates on that map, while

the Mosers' "grid cells" create the little
blue dot on the map that tells you where you
are.

So thanks to this year's Nobel laureates for
helping us see life at the microscopic level,

understand how we know where we are, and for
making it possible for you to see me right

now. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow
News. If you want us help us educate the world

on the awesomeness of science, which we couldn't
do without support from people like you, you

can become a supporting subscriber at subbable.com/scishow.
And if you just want to keep getting smarter

with us, you can go to youtube.com/scishow
and subscribe.
